<p>When declaring variables that large you can use <strong>scientific notation</strong></p>
<p><a href="http://python-reference.readthedocs.io/en/latest/docs/float/scientific.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">http://python-reference.readthedocs.io/en/latest/docs/float/scientific.html</a></p>
<p>and to get "very large decimal values" on division operations you can use string formatting and scientific notation</p>
<p><a href="https://www.reddit.com/r/learnpython/comments/1vpmyl/how_do_i_convert_a_number_to_scientific_notation/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://www.reddit.com/r/learnpython/comments/1vpmyl/how_do_i_convert_a_number_to_scientific_notation/</a></p>

<span class="comment-copy">Are you just looking for large numbers, or large numbers with high precision? A <code>float</code> only keeps as much information as it can cram into 64 bits; if you want dozen of digits worth, you want to use <code>decimal.Decimal</code>. Start by reading <a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/decimal.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">the module docs</a>; there's a lot to learn, but it's worth it.</span>
